claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.
explanation: Four‐panel figure showing, in two age groups (18–44 and 45–64 years), (A and B) geometric mean ratios (with 95% CIs) of hemagglutination inhibition titers against egg‐grown versus cell‐grown vaccine virus for four vaccine types (Fluzone IIV4 and Fluarix IIV4 egg‐based, ccIIV4 cell‐based, and RIV4 recombinant) and (C and D) pre‐ and post‐vaccination proportions of subjects with ≥4‐fold reduced titers to cell‐grown vaccine virus for each vaccine type and strain (A(H3N2), A(H1N1)pdm09, B/VIC, B/YAM), with p‐values indicating significant differences. Evidence: Panels A and B show that both egg‐based (Fluzone, Fluarix) and cell‐based (ccIIV4) vaccines elicit significantly higher titers to egg‐grown virus than to cell‐grown virus (geometric mean ratios >1, p<0.05), and Panels C and D show nonzero proportions of ≥4‐fold reduced titers to cell virus after ccIIV4 immunization, indicating antigenic mismatch likely due to production‐associated mutations. The data demonstrate that vaccine strains grown in eggs or in cell culture acquire antigenic changes that reduce antibody recognition of the cell‐grown virus, which supports the claim Note: Interpretation is based on HAI titer ratios as a proxy for antigenic changes; the figure does not show direct sequencing of mutations. Assay context and vaccine strain specifics may introduce variability.
